The course featured occasional "asynchronous" sessions in which the class did not meet, but instead students were required to work alone or in pairs to complete work by or during the usual class time.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A broadened vocabulary and knowledge of Japanese grammar. I am now able to hold very basic conversations about a variety of topics.
I learned a lot of grammar and new vocabulary words.
I learned various aspects of Japanese including grammar, vocabulary, and culture.
Japanese reading, writing, speaking
L3 Grammar, Kanji, Vocabulary. Also accent and listening skills.
I got better at speaking japanese

The homework load is high and especially time consuming. I found all homework assignments valuable, but do felt that the amount of work required on a daily basis was stress-inducing and taxing to the point that it was at times counterproductive to the learning objective. Having too much work causes mental exhaustion and fatigue toward the topic, reducing the student's ability to meaningfully study and retain the information and their motivation to review and study further beyond completion of assigned work. All of the same assignments could be still be given, but in reduced volume, so that students would better engage with the work.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: during class, you speak almost the entire time which helps you repetitively practice the vocab, grammar, and pronunciation. We also did some karaoke which was a fun way to learn as well :)
Weaknesses: This class requires A LOT of your attention. You have to be very engaged and spend time studying and practicing the kanji, vocab, and grammar. There is a lot of homework (kanji and grammar worksheets, listening/reading comprehension, Writing practice, speaking drills) which is assigned nightly as well as nightly kanji quizzes. It definitely is a lot and can be stressful, but it is very rewarding when you look back and see the progress in your language abilities.

This course was really excellent; I always looked forward to going to class, knowing that it would be fun and I would learn a lot. So, this class has very few areas for improvement: only two that I can think of. First, we didn't learn a lot of kanji. I found myself studying kanji in my own time because of how little kanji we were learning in class. Second, we didn't practice a lot of impromptu speaking. The drills and classroom discussions were always very structured with specific grammar structures we were expected to use. Thus, if we're ever asked to speak to a native speaker, we may have some trouble due to our lack of practice in impromptu speaking.
I believe that I improved my speaking greatly but my knowledge of kanji definitely needed improvement.
Great training in pronunciation. Homework is a bit too much, however.
Teacher was great and I learned a lot. I got lots of good practice in as well.
The class was very good considering the pandemic

The homework load is high and especially time consuming. I found all homework assignments valuable, but do felt that the amount of work required on a daily basis was stress-inducing and taxing to the point that it was at times counterproductive to the learning objective. Having too much work causes mental exhaustion and fatigue toward the topic, reducing the student's ability to meaningfully study and retain the information and their motivation to review and study further beyond completion of assigned work. All of the same assignments could be still be given, but in reduced volume, so that students would better engage with the work.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved how this class was mostly in breakout rooms. Not only did I get to meet my classmates and speak with them on a more intimate level, but I also got to practice speaking Japanese with my classmates and engage in conversation.
I think that the breakout rooms in Zoom were fun ways to practice Japanese.

The slides created for speaking drills and practice were great. Also small breakout rooms were used well. While I was worried that it would be hard to learn a language virtually, the effort of the teacher made the class work very well.
All succeeded

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it taught me a lot.

Absolutely!  is an incredible teacher and is very kind. She really helps you to grow and enjoy the process of learning a new language. I am very pleased with my progress in the Japanese Language program, especially having come to college knowing almost no Japanese.

Yes! Nishimura Sensei is so great, and I learned so much this semester. One thing to be aware of is there is a lot of homework, which can be tedious sometimes. Plus, you have class everyday, which means you have homework to do every day.
I would for anyone interested in delving deeper into the Japanese language.
Yes.
Yes, if you are interested in Japanese. The teacher is great and you learn a lot.
Yes, it is good for learning japanese
